div1.p: Lazear discusses the weather, Edinburgh, the anatomy department, and the Scots.

div1.head: Letter from Jesse W. Lazear to Charlotte C. Sweitzer, June 24, 1890
div1.p:
Your letter of June 9. reached
me this morning. I enjoyed it very much,
as I do all your letters. The pleasure
of getting letters is increased by
the distance we are apart.

It sometimes seems very peculiar
to be a foreigner. There are always
Americans here, I can often
spot them. Some of the hotels here
fly an American flag in order
to attract American tourists,
that seems rather ridiculous.
When we buy things here we
always have to try to conceal
our nationality in order not to
be charged double prices Americans
are all considered to be rich.

It is very strange that the Lyons
behave badly to Gus Murdoch, I
have no doubt both he and
May, will be glad when they had
are married and are rid of the
whole lot.

I can hardly imagine that you have
hot weather. It has been cool
here all along. I am now entirely
used to it, and never wear an
overcoat. The temperature is very
even but it rains a great deal
almost every day. I did not
know that the candy here was
good. I will proceed to sample
some of it. As to Edinburgh
growing on you, I cannot say
that I have experienced such
a feeling. A certain section of
the town is very beautiful. Hand-
some cottages with large grounds
surrounded by high walls, narrow
lanes running between them. I
never tire of that part of the town
but I appreciated it perfectly
the first time I saw it. The
rest of the town including
the principal streets is very
tiresome. Princes St. is the great
street of the town, along our
side are the large shops, hotels
etc, and on the other there is
a park with some monuments.
That sounds as though it might
be pretty but somehow the effect
does not please me and this street
bores me more than any other.
I had always heard that
sensational advertisements
were peculiarly American but
I have seen some here that beat
anything on the other side
There is a grocer here who
sends around a regular army
of “sandwich-men” dressed
in most gorgeous uniforms
some on foot and some on
horseback there are thirty odd
of them.

A few days ago, the Lord Mayor of
London made a state visit to
Edinburgh to see the exhibition
and I was fortunate enough
to see him in his coach. In the
distance I thought it was
a fire engine. There was
a man riding ahead and one
behind. Then there was a coachman
and two footmen in knee-breeches
white stockings and powdered wig
according to the old custom.
The Lord mayors him self is a big
intelligent looking old gentleman
He is a Jew and his name is Sir
Henry Isaacs.

I am glad to hear that Charley
Orr is coming over, I hope that
I shall meet him. I know he
will enjoy the trip for he is
a very observant traveller.

The instructors in the Anatomy
department here are very fine men
and thy have been remarkably
Kind to us. We had an examination
yesterday on the Thorax. They gave
us a special examination as
the regular one had been held before
we came, and one of the demon-
strators volunteered to give us
a quiz beforehand on the subject.
He talked to us for over two hours
and gave us some very valuable
instruction. There was no necessity
for him to do this and he only
did it because he liked it.
They all have the air of teaching
not because they are employed
to do so but because they
would rather do it than do
anything else, They I should
think that they would get very
tired and discouraged, as the
students are terribly dull, but
they never loose lose patience
nor seem annoyed at all.
They are nearly all Englishmen;
in fact all but one and he
is an Irishman, Poor Scotland.

Nothing has occurred worthy of
note since I wrote last night.
Give my love to all, including the McCallams
